thread.title: Ranking every running of the Great American Race
thread.title_full: Ranking every running of the Great American Race

author: Brian
title: Ranking every running of the Great American Race

organizations.name: getty images getty images for nascar

text:
Feb 6, 2017 at 9:44a ET 0Shares 
The 59 th running of the Daytona 500 takes place Feb. 26 at 2 p.m. ET on FOX. To help get you ready, we rank the 58 previous editions of the Great American Race from worst to best. ISC Archives via Getty Images RacingOne 57 2003 
No disrespect to race-winner Michael Waltrip, but we’re ranking this one 58 th because it’s the shortest Daytona 500 ever run — just 109 laps or 272.5 miles were completed before being called due to rain. Getty Images Getty Images 56 1965 Rain shortens the Daytona 500 to just 333 miles, as Fred “The Golden Boy” Lorenzen cruises to victory in No. 28 Holman-Moody Ford. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 55 2009 Elliott Sadler dominates, but when rain comes after 380 miles, it’s Matt Kenseth who is declared the winner in the third-shortest Daytona 500 ever. Getty Images Getty Images for NASCAR 54 1973 The fourth of seven 500 wins for King Richard Petty, who wins by a full two laps over fellow future NASCAR Hall of Fame member Bobby Isaac. This is the largest margin of victory in Daytona 500 history. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 53 1964 Richard Petty dominates the field, leading 184 of 200 laps to drub the competition and win the first of his record-setting seven Daytona 500s. Petty lapped the entire field. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 52 1972 In one of the least competitive Daytona 500s ever, A.J. Foyt leads 167 laps, with the only other drivers to lead laps being Bobby Allison (2 laps led) and Richard Petty (31). The racing really wasn’t better back then. Getty Images Chris Trotman 51 1991 Under caution, Ernie Irvan wins in the powerhouse Morgan-McClure Chevrolet over Sterling Marlin. Ironically, Marlin would go on to replace Irvan in 1994 after he leaves the team to join Robert Yates. Focus on Sport Focus on Sport/Getty Images 50 2000 The yellow flag is out as Dale Jarrett wins his third and final Daytona 5oo, as Jeff Burton, Bill Elliott, Rusty Wallace and Mark Martin make it an all-Ford top five. Michael L. Levitt /LAT USA 49 2015 For the second consecutive year, the Daytona 500 finishes under the yellow flag, this one resulting in Joey Logano winning. It’s just the second time Roger Penske is the winning Daytona 500 team owner. ©, Michael L. Levitt ©2015, Michael L. Levitt 48 2006 With the yellow flag flying, seven-time NASCAR Premier Series champion Jimmie Johnson takes his first Daytona 500 win over Casey Mears. MCT via Getty Images 47 2014 Another Daytona 500 that ends under caution, but this one makes a lot of fans deliriously happy as Dale Earnhardt Jr. wins his second Daytona 500. MCT MCT via Getty Images 46 1966 Richard Petty, a/k/a “The King,” laps the entire field to win his second of a record seven Daytona 500 race victories. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 45 1975 A popular victory for the popular Benny Parsons, who wins his only Daytona 500 by lapping the entire field, including Bobby Allison and his second-place Penske AMC Matador. Robert Alexander Getty Images 44 1981 Richard Petty wins his seventh and final Daytona 500 over Bobby Allison and Ricky Rudd. After previously winning in Plymouths (1964, ’66 and ’71), Dodges (1973-74) and an Oldsmobile (1979), Petty wins his last 500 piloting a Buick. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 43 1982 J.D. Stacy sponsors seven of the 42 cars in the field, but it’s the No. 88 Gatorade Buick driven by Bobby Allison that makes it to Victory Lane as Allison wins his second of three Daytona 500s. Bob Harmeyer Getty Images 42 1974 The fifth of seven Daytona 500 victories for Richard Petty, who defeats Cale Yarborough by 47 seconds, or nearly a full lap. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 41 1983 In a tight battle with upcoming star Bill Elliott, Cale Yarborough wins his third of four Daytona 500s and his first since 1977. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 40 1971 How’s this for a top five? Richard Petty wins over teammate Buddy Baker, followed by A.J. Foyt, David Pearson and Fred Lorenzen. That’s stout company. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 39 1984 A year earlier, Cale Yarborough won the Daytona 500 in a Harry Ranier-owned Pontiac. This time, he wins in a Ranier Chevrolet ahead of Dale Earnhardt and Darrell Waltrip. It’s Yarborough’s fourth and final Daytona 500 victory. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 38 1961 Pontiacs sweep the top three spots, with Marvin Panch driving Smokey Yunick’s year-old car to a win over Joe Weatherly and Paul Goldsmith. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 37 1985 Bill Elliott leads 136 of 200 laps to win his first Daytona 500, but at the checkered flag, his margin over Lake Speed is just 0.94 seconds. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 36 1978 
In his 17 th attempt, NASCAR Hall of Fame member Bobby Allison scores the first of his three Daytona 500 victories. Cale Yarborough is the only other driver to finish on the lead lap with Allison. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 35 1996 It’s Part 2 of the Dale and Dale show, with Dale Jarrett and his No. 88 Robert Yates Racing Ford holding off the black No. 3 Richard Childress Racing Chevrolet of Dale Earnhardt. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 34 1986 Geoff Bodine gives a young car owner named Rick Hendrick his first Daytona 500 victory, defeating future Hendrick Motorsports drivers Terry Labonte and Darrell Waltrip. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 33 2002 In just its second year back in NASCAR, Dodge pulls off a huge upset as Ward Burton wins his only Daytona 500 in a Bill Davis Racing Dodge Intrepid. WireImage Kevin Kane 32 1977 In a close battle with Benny Parsons, Cale Yarborough wins his second of three Daytona 500s by just 1.39 seconds. 31 1992 After finishing second to his father Bobby in 1998, Davey Allison scores an enormously popular victory in his Robert Yates Racing Ford. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 30 1987 In the last Daytona 500 run without restrictor plates, Bill Elliott wins the Daytona 500 for the second time in three years, holding off Benny Parsons in a battle of NASCAR Hall of Fame members. Focus on Sport Focus on Sport/Getty Images 29 1968 It’s an all-Mercury shootout as Cale Yarborough holds off LeeRoy Yarbrough — no relation — giving the Wood Brothers another Daytona 500 victory. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 28 2005 Jeff Gordon’s third and final Daytona victory comes after a tight battle with Kurt Busch’s Roush Fenway Racing Ford, which crosses the line just 0.158 seconds back of the No. 24 Hendrick Motorsports Chevrolet. This content is subject to copyright. Sporting News via Getty Images 27 2012 The 2012 Daytona 500 lives on in sports infamy, not because Matt Kenseth wins it for a second time, but because Juan Pablo Montoya runs into a jet dryer under caution, triggering a brief inferno. Getty Images Getty Images for NASCAR 26 1960 Junior Johnson becomes the first driver to figure out the concept of drafting at Daytona and uses it to pull away to an easy victory in a year-old Chevrolet. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 25 2013 Coming to the white flag, rookie Danica Patrick is running third ahead of Dale Earnhardt Jr. but it’s Jimmie Johnson who holds on for his second Daytona 500 victory. Brian Czobat / autostock © 271 Fryling Ave SW Concord, NC 28025 W 704.786.2919 C 704.904.2745 autostock/Brian Czobat 24 1999 Jeff Gordon holds off defending race winner Dale Earnhardt by a mere 0.128 seconds to win his second Daytona 500 in a thrilling battle between two of NASCAR’s all-time best drivers. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 23 2010 Jamie McMurray kicks off a dream season with a victory in NASCAR’s biggest race. He would go on to win the Brickyard 400 and the fall Charlotte race later that year. Getty Images Getty Images for NASCAR 22 1970 With Maurice Petty as his crew chief, New Englander Pete Hamilton drives the winged No. 40 Petty Enterprises Plymouth Superbird to victory. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 21 1967 Open–wheel star Mario Andretti drives a Holman-Moody Ford to victory, becoming the first and so far only foreign-born driver to win the Great American Race. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 20 1997 Although the race ends under caution, Jeff Gordon leads teammates Terry Labonte and Ricky Craven to a 1-2-3 Hendrick Motorsports sweep, just weeks after team owner Rick Hendrick was diagnosed with chronic myelogenous leukemia. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 19 1962 Fireball Roberts dominates the beach in ‘62, winning his Daytona 500 qualifying racing, beating Richard Petty to win the 500 and then returning in July to win the Firecracker 250. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 18 1980 Driving an Oldsmobile nicknamed “The Gray Ghost,” Buddy Baker sets a speed record that remains intact, averaging 177.602 miles per hour in the fastest Daytona 500 in history. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 17 2004 In the first of his two Daytona 500 victories, Dale Earnhardt Jr. leads 58 laps, while second-place finisher Tony Stewart leads a race-high 98 circuits but can’t seal the deal. 16 1989 This one might have been fate. In his 17 th Daytona 500 start, Darrell Waltrip drives the No. 17 Hendrick Motorsports Chevrolet to an emotional victory, after which he dances in Victory Lane. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 15 1969 LeeRoy Yarbrough comes from behind and drives Junior Johnson’s Ford past Charlie Glotzbach’s Cotton Owens-owned Dodge on the backstretch on the final lap to win a thriller. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 14 1994 Sterling Marlin wins his first NASCAR Premier Series race in 279 attempts, driving the Morgan-McClure McClure Motorsports Chevrolet to victory, edging Ernie Irvan’s Ford at the line by 0.19 seconds. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 13 1990 Dale Earnhardt dominates the race, but on the last lap he runs over a piece of Ricky Rudd’s bell-housing and cuts a tire heading into Turn 3, opening the door for an upset victory by Derrike Cope. 12 2008 For all his success at the Indianapolis 500, team owner Roger Penske doesn’t win the Daytona 500 until 2008, when Kurt Busch pushes teammate Ryan Newman to the victory by just 0.092 seconds and a 1-2 Team Penske sweep. Getty Images for NASCAR Robert Laberge 11 1963 In the preliminary sports car race at Daytona, Wood Brothers Racing driver Marvin Panch flips his Maserati, which burst into flames. Tiny Lund sees the crash and pulls Panch out of the burning car. In gratitude, the Woods ask Lund to drive in the 500, which he goes on to win. Lund is the only driver to win NASCAR’s biggest race on a single set of tires. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 10 2007 
Kevin Harvick comes out of nowhere on the last lap to edge Mark Martin by half a fender in a thrilling finish. Behind them, as they race to the checkered flag, a huge crash takes out a number of cars, including Clint Bowyer’s Chevrolet, which flips and catches fire. Getty Images Getty Images for NASCAR 9 1988 In an extremely popular finish, Bobby Allison wins over son Davey, the only time in history that a father-son combination finished 1-2 in the Daytona 500. At age 50, Bobby becomes the oldest 500 winner. Focus on Sport Focus on Sport/Getty Images 8 2016 Five Toyota drivers race in lockstep over the closing laps, with Denny Hamlin edging Martin Truex Jr. at the start-finish line by 0.010 seconds in the closest Daytona 500 finish since the advent of electronic timing and scoring. NASCAR NASCAR via Getty Images 7 2011 In one of the greatest upsets in sports history, Trevor Bayne captures the Daytona 500 in only his second career NASCAR Premier Series start. Bayne’s victory, which comes one day after he turns 20, is the first for the Wood Brothers in a decade. © Nigel Kinrade 1240 Briers Creek Drive Alpharetta, Georgia 30004 Nigel Kinrade/Autostock 6 2001 Michael Waltrip breaks an 0-for-462 streak to win his first NASCAR points race ahead of Dale Earnhardt Inc. teammate Dale Earnhardt Jr. But on the last corner of the last lap, team owner and seven-time NASCAR Premier Series champion Dale Earnhardt is killed in a crash. Getty Images 5 1993 With father Ned Jarrett in the TV booth calling the dramatic finish and nervous mother Martha in the motorhome, Dale Jarrett holds off Dale Earnhardt on the last lap to win what becomes known as “The Dale and Dale show.” Bob Harmeyer Getty Images 4 1998 Dale Earnhardt ends 20 years of frustration by finally winning the Daytona 500. Afterward, virtually every crewmember in the entire garage lines up along pit road to salute The Man in Black as he rolls by in the black No. 3 Richard Childress Racing Chevy. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 3 1959 Petty family patriarch Lee Petty captures the inaugural Daytona 500 in a photo finish that isn’t made official until the following Wednesday. This race helps put NASCAR on the national map. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images 2 1979 Richard Petty wins his sixth Daytona 500 after Cale Yarborough and Donnie Allison crash on the backstretch on the last lap. Afterward, Yarborough brawls with Bobby and Donnie Allison in NASCAR’s most famous fight. With the East Coast snowed in and a huge TV audience, this race draws national attention for the sport. 1 1976 On the last lap, NASCAR legends Richard Petty and David Pearson wreck each other going for the victory, with Pearson able to re-fire his Wood Brothers Racing Mercury and limp across the finish line for the victory. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images
